A custom directive is not defined in an implementing service. All custom directives must be defined across all implementing services, even if some of those definitions are a no-op.
A custom directive is defined inconsistently across services. A directive's arguments and argument types, along with its supported schema locations, must match across all services.
A scalar type is defined multiple times in a single service.
An enum type is defined multiple times in a single service.
One of an enum type's values is defined multiple times. Duplicate values can be in either the enum's originating service or another service that extends the enum.
An enum's values do not match across all services. Even if a service does not use all enum values, they still must be provided if another service uses them.

type name as the root subscription object. This is not allowed.
Multiple implementing services define the same value type, but with mismatched fields. Value types must match across all services that define them.
Multiple implementing services define the same value type, but with mismatched input values for fields. Value types and input values for fields must match across all services that define them.

Multiple implementing services define the same union type, but with mismatched sets of types. Union types must match across all services that define them.

node.excerpt: In Apollo Federation, an entity is an object typeâ€¦

children.value: is an object type that you define canonically in
implementing service and can then reference and extend in
implementing services. Entities are the core building block of a federated graph.
In a GraphQL schema, you can designate any object type as an entity by adding a
directive to its definition, like so:
, which consists of one or more of the type's
field. The gateway's query planner uses an entity's primary key to identify a given instance of the type.
cannot include fields that return a union or interface.
If an entity can be uniquely identified by more than one combination of fields, you can define more than one primary key for that entity.

This explicit syntax has several benefits:
It enables you to run the
service standalone with a valid schema, including a
It provides strong typing information that lets you catch mistakes at schema composition time.

The gateway provides this representation to the entity's originating service to fetch the full object. For this to work, the originating service (in this case,
Reference resolvers are a special addition to Apollo Server that enable entities to be referenced by other services. They are called whenever a query references an
across service boundaries. To learn more about

With this model, each implementing service's schema represents a true subset of the complete data graph. This prevents the need for defining foreign-key fields in individual schemas, and enables clients to transparently execute a query like the following, which hits both the

When a service extends an entity, the entity's
service is not aware of the added fields. Only the
service (along with the gateway) knows about these fields.
Each field of an entity should be defined in exactly one service. Otherwise, a schema composition error will occur.

properties.ariaLabel: resolving another services field advanced permalink

children.value: Sometimes, multiple implementing services are capable of resolving a particular field for an entity, because all of those services have access to a particular data store. For example, an
service might both have access to the database that stores all product-related data.
in this case, you can specify that the extending service
This is a completely optional optimization.

When the gateway plans a query's execution, it looks at which fields are available from each implementing service. It can then attempt to optimize performance by executing the query across the fewest services needed to access all required fields.
Keep the following in mind when using the
a field must also define a resolver for that field.
That resolver's behavior must match the behavior of the resolver in the field's originating service.
When an entity's field can be fetched from multiple services, there is no guarantee as to
service will resolve that field for a particular query.
a field, it must still list that field as
, because the field originates in another service.

node.excerpt: This content is meant for developers addingâ€¦

children.value: This content is meant for developers adding federation support to alternative GraphQL servers, and for anyone curious about the inner workings of federation. It is not needed to use or understand federation when using Apollo Server.
To make a GraphQL service federation capable, it needs the following:
Implementation of the federation schema specification
Implementation of stub type generation for references
Implementation of request resolving for entities.
Federated services will need to implement the following additions to the schema to allow the gateway to use the service for execution:
# a union of all types that use the @key directive
# this is an optional directive discussed below
For more information on these additions, see the
Schema composition at the gateway requires having each service's schema, annotated with its federation configuration. This information is fetched from each service using
, an enhanced introspection entry point added to the query root of each federated service.
field is not exposed by the gateway; it is solely for internal use.
type which has a single field called
. This SDL (schema definition language) is a printed version of the service's schema
the annotations of federation directives. This SDL does
include the additions of the federation spec above. Given an input like this:
The generated SDL should match that exactly with no additions. It is important to preserve the type extensions and directive locations and to omit the federation types.
don't have native support for type extensions in their printer. Apollo Federation supports using an
Individual federated services should be runnable without having the entire graph present. Fields marked with
are declarations of fields that are defined in another service. All fields referred to in
fields in the same service. This allows us to be explicit about dependencies on another service, and service composition will verify that an
field matches up with the original field definition, which can catch mistakes or migration issues (when the original field changes its type for example).

fields also give an individual service the type information it needs to validate and decode incoming representations (this is especially important for custom scalars), without requiring the composed graph schema to be available at runtime in each service.
A federated service should take the
fields and types and create them locally so the service can run on its own.
Execution of a federated graph requires being able to "enter" into a service at an entity type. To do this, federated services need to do two things:
Make each entity in the schema part of the
union. If no types are annotated with the key directive, then the
field should be removed from the schema. For example, given the following partial schema:
union for that partial schema should be the following:
union is critical to support the
Queries across service boundaries will start off from the

root field. The resolver for this field receives a list of representations. A representation is a blob of data that is supposed to match the combined requirements of the fields requested on an entity.
For example, if we execute a query for the top product's
The gateway will first fetch the
from the Products service, asking for the
is because that field is specified as a requirement on
The gateway will then send a list of representations for the fetched products to the Reviews service:
GraphQL execution will then go over each representation in the list, use the
to match type conditions, build up a merged selection set, and execute it. Here, the inline fragment on
resolver will be called repeatedly with the representation for each product. Since
union, it can be selected as a return of the

To ensure the required fields are provided, and of the right type, the source object properties should coerce the input into the expected type for the property (by calling parseValue on the scalar type).
The real resolver will then be able to access the required properties from the (partial) object:

directive, including both types native to the schema and extended types.

directive is used to indicate a combination of fields that can be used to uniquely identify and fetch an object or interface.
Multiple keys can be defined on a single object type:

directive is used to annotate the expected returned fieldset from a field on a base type that is guaranteed to be selectable by the gateway. Given the following example:

directive is used to annotate the required input fieldset from a base type for a resolver. It is used to develop a query plan where the required fields may not be needed by the client, but the service may need additional information from other services. For example:
In this case, the Reviews service adds new capabilities to the
type by providing a list of
related to a user. In order to fetch these reviews, the Reviews service needs to know the
from the Users service in order to look up the reviews. This means the
directive is used to mark a field as owned by another service. This allows service A to use fields from service B while also knowing at runtime the types of that field. For example:

type from the Users service. It extends it for the purpose of adding a new field called
